title: How justice falls through the cracks of a Taiwan-Hong Kong legal loophole
text:
The dispute between Hong Kong and Taiwan over the voluntary return of a murder suspect to the island to stand trial highlights the struggle Taiwanese authorities have to fight such crimes without a judicial agreement with the city.

Hong Kong resident Chan Tong-kai allegedly killed his 20-year-old girlfriend Poon Hiu-wing during a holiday in Taiwan early last year and returned to Hong Kong soon after.

Chan’s case was one of the main factors behind the Hong Kong government’s decision to introduce an extradition bill that would have allowed criminal suspects to be transferred to jurisdictions – including Taiwan and mainland China – with which the city has no agreement.

But opposition to the bill erupted into the city’s biggest political crisis in decades and resulted in the complete withdrawal of the proposed legislation.

Chan has said he is willing to voluntarily surrender to authorities in Taiwan but over the last week, Hong Kong and Taipei have failed to agree on how that should take place.

Taiwan has offered to send officers to pick up the suspect but the Hong Kong government has dismissed the suggestion as “totally unacceptable” and “disrespectful” of the city’s jurisdictional power.

Taipei District Court judge Lin Meng-huang said that even though Taipei and Beijing had a joint agreement to fight crime, the Hong Kong government had been reluctant to have any official judicial contact with the island.

“This has made things difficult for Taiwan when it comes to intercepting Taiwanese or foreign suspects who may flee to Hong Kong from Taiwan,” Lin said.

“Hong Kong is unwilling to have an official form of judicial cooperation with the Taiwan side, so suspects get away.”

He said that in another case, Hong Kong froze the equivalent of NT$6.4 billion (now worth US$200 million) held in bank accounts in the city by the ringleader of an illegal lottery in 2006 but refused to hand over the money to the island’s authorities because there was no legal framework to do so.

And in August, Taiwanese police sought help to freeze the Hong Kong bank account of a telecom fraud suspect only for the city to reject the request on the same grounds.

According to the island’s Ministry of Justice, there is no direct judicial channel between Taiwan and Hong Kong, and all requests for help from Taiwan go through the island’s representative office in Hong Kong.

“Since 2016, we have sent 53 requests for judicial cooperation with Hong Kong, but the Hong Kong side has never responded,” a ministry spokesman said.

But Taiwan had been willing to help Hong Kong, ministry officials said, citing the return of three murder suspects to the city in 2016.

The officials said Taiwan had a much easier time working with other jurisdictions.

According to the Criminal Investigation Department, the island has posted liaison officers in the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Japan.

It had also strived to set up more liaison offices in the United States, Canada, European Union and Australia to extend its cross-border investigation and intelligence network, the department said

In addition to exchanging information with those countries, the offices helped the island expose telecom frauds and trafficking and send fugitives back to the island to stand trial.

“Although Taiwan is not a member of Interpol, it has judicial cooperation – either formal or informal – with many countries in the world,” a department spokesman said.

For example, recent cooperation with Portugal resulted in the arrest of 19 suspects in the Portuguese resort Cascais and two others in Taiwan, he said.

Lin, the district court judge, said Taiwan also sent five police officers and prosecutors to Macau in 2005 in relation to the kidnapping of the son of a Taiwanese tycoon. Lin said Macau’s prosecutors agreed to interrogate several suspects accused of the crime using questions provided by the Taiwanese side.
